Key Considerations for Temporary Solutions:

None of these will make under your deck bone dry, but they should definitely help decrease the direct assault of raindrops and allow your mosquito netting to continue its noble work with a bit less of a drenching, all while keeping the breezes flowing.

How it works: Lay these directly on the deck surface. A good quality, thick canvas or a synthetic outdoor fabric (like those used for awnings or boat covers, but perhaps a lighter version) can repel a surprising amount of water, especially if the rain isn't a torrential downpour. Water will tend to bead up and run off the edges, particularly if there's a slight slope.
Pros: Relatively inexpensive, easy to deploy and remove, widely available. Still allows for some breathability, especially canvas. You can cut them to size.
Cons: Not fully waterproof; heavy or prolonged rain will eventually saturate them. You'll need to secure them against wind (weights, clips, etc.). They'll need to be dried out properly to prevent mildew if they get soaked. Aesthetics might be a bit... utilitarian.
For your KC climate: Should handle the elements fine for temporary use.

How it works: A large outdoor rug made of synthetic materials (polypropylene, olefin) can absorb some initial rainfall and deflect some of it, causing it to run off the sides rather than straight through the deck boards.
Pros: Can look nicer than a plain tarp. Easy to put down. Provides some comfort underfoot on the deck itself.
Cons: Their primary job isn't waterproofing. Many are designed to dry quickly, meaning they are also quite permeable. They will reduce, but not stop, water flow. Heavy ones can be a pain to move when wet. Need to be cleaned and dried to avoid becoming a science experiment.
Look for: Rugs specifically marketed as "water-resistant" rather than just "outdoor."

How it works: Think of those roll-up bamboo fences or beach mats. Laid flat on the deck, they won't stop water, but they can significantly break up the direct flow of raindrops, causing water to disperse and run along the reeds/bamboo before finding its way through the gaps. This can reduce the intensity of drips below.
Pros: Very breathable. Can be aesthetically pleasing in a natural way. Relatively cheap and easy to roll up and store.
Cons: Minimal water blocking; it's more about diffusion and slowing the flow. Durability might be an issue with frequent wetting and foot traffic.

How it works: You could lay down sections of these tiles in key areas. The perforations mean airflow isn't cut, but the solid parts of the tiles will deflect direct raindrops. Water will go around the solid bits and through the holes.
Pros: Durable, easy to clean, good airflow. Can be configured as needed.
Cons: Water will definitely still go through the perforations. May not reduce water volume underneath as much as fabric options. Can be a bit industrial looking unless you find stylish ones.

Securing them: Wind is your enemy here. Plan how you'll keep your chosen solution from becoming a kite.
Drying: Whatever you use, if it gets wet (and it will), you'll need to be able to dry it out to prevent mold, mildew, and general funkiness. This is especially true for fabrics and rugs.
Slope: Even a slight slope on your deck will help any of these options encourage water to run off the edges rather than pooling and seeping.

Cons: Effectiveness varies greatly by product. May not provide a 100% dry space underneath unless specifically designed as a "waterproof decking system." Debris can get caught in channels.

What it is: If your current deck boards are due for replacement, some composite decking systems, when installed with appropriate gasketing or sealing between boards (or specifically designed interlocking edges), can create a more water-resistant surface.
Pros: Long-lasting, low maintenance.
Cons: This is a more significant project than just an overlay. Not all composite systems are designed to be fully waterproof.

Okay, this isn't strictly on top of your current deck boards, but it's a common solution and worth a brief mention if the above don't suit. These systems involve installing waterproof troughs or panels between the deck joists, underneath your existing deck boards. The water drips through the deck boards, is caught by these channels, and is then directed to a gutter system.
Pros: Very effective at creating a dry space. Can be retrofitted to existing decks (though boards may need to be temporarily removed).
Cons: More labor-intensive. Requires careful installation to ensure proper slope and drainage.

Deck Slope: For any of these to work well, your deck needs a slight slope (ideally about 1/4 inch per foot) away from the house to ensure water drains off and doesn't pool. If it's dead flat or slopes the wrong way, that's a problem to solve first.
Deck Structure: Ensure your deck's structure is sound and can handle any added weight or alterations.
Ventilation: If you completely seal the underside, ensure there's still adequate ventilation to prevent moisture buildup and potential rot or mold issues for the framing.

When an RDP client tries to connect, before it even thinks about asking for your credentials or painting a remote desktop, it does a few crucial things under the hood:

DNS Resolution: It takes the server name you provided (e.g., myserver.corp.net) and asks a DNS server, "What's the IP address for this?" If it can't get an IP address, it stops right there. You'd typically get an error like "The remote computer could not be found."

TCP Handshake on Port 3389: Once it has an IP address, the RDP client attempts to establish a TCP connection to that IP address on port 3389 (the standard RDP listener port). This is a three-way handshake (SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK).

So, to "see if the server is there" in the way RDP does before attempting the full connection, you want to mimic that TCP handshake on port 3389.

The best way to automate this with a script in your Windows environment is precisely what the PowerShell script I provided earlier uses:

Why Test-NetConnection on the RDP port is better than ping for your use case:

Other tools/methods (less ideal for your scripting but good for understanding):

In summary, for your scripting needs to automate the check RDP effectively performs initially, Test-NetConnection -Port 3389 is your most accurate and readily available tool on Windows. The script I provided already incorporates this as the primary check for RDP availability, along with checking name resolution first.

If a firewall (network firewall, Windows Firewall on the server, or something like Zscaler intercepting and deciding) blocks traffic to this port, the handshake fails.
If there's no service listening on port 3389 on the server (e.g., Remote Desktop Services isn't running or is configured for a different port), the handshake also fails.
This is typically when you see the error "cannot establish a connection with the remote computer" or similar messages like "Remote Desktop can't connect to the remote computer for one of these reasons..." where network connectivity is implied.

Test-NetConnection -ComputerName <ServerNameOrIP> -Port 3389:
This PowerShell cmdlet specifically attempts to establish a TCP connection to the specified port on the target server.

If TcpTestSucceeded is True, it means the server is reachable on that port, and something is listening – very much like RDP's initial check.
If it's False, then RDP would also fail at this early stage.

Direct Relevance: It checks the exact port RDP uses. Ping checks general network reachability via ICMP, which is often treated differently by network policies.
Firewall Friendliness (Relatively): If RDP is supposed to work, then port 3389 must be open through all firewalls (including Zscaler policies). ICMP can be blocked independently.
Service Indication: A successful TCP connection to port 3389 strongly suggests that the Remote Desktop Services (or at least a service) is listening on that port.

telnet (if installed): telnet your-server-name 3389. If the screen goes blank or shows some cryptic characters, it connected. If it errors out, it didn't. This is a more old-school way of doing what Test-NetConnection does.
